65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:39): implied elements are weird
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (04:53): implied elements make script authors do a lot more work
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:54): Implied elements mean we don't have to check if there's actually a tbody present. Then XHTML comes along and ruins it
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (04:54): when I author a document, I expect the markup to be represented in the DOM just as I wrote the markup
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (04:55): if I could rely on that, I wouldn't have to do screwy tests to find out what the DOM thinks the markup should be
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (04:55): so the author ends up having to do extra tests
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:55): Implied elements are predictable
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (04:56): to expert authors, probably so
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (04:56): but most authors are not expert
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (04:57): I prefer wysiwyg DOM parsing
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (04:58): Hypothesis: Most authors wouldn't predict <tbody>
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:58): Hypothesis: Most authors either use .tBodies[0] because they were told to, or use getElementsByTagName('tr') and don't care about the tbody
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (04:58): I suspect most authors don't even know <tbody> exists
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (04:59): Everybody always includes <html> and <head> and <body> even though those could easily be omitted and implied
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (05:00): so it seems people don't understand the concept of implied elements to an extent that they intentionally make use of it
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (05:00): I say, the less voodoo the better
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (05:01): 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: Well, have fun with your documentElement when <html> is implied
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (05:02): why would I not include an <html> element?
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (05:02): I would expect and hope for an error if I tried to do that
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (05:02): (use documentElement if I didn't have an <html> element)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (05:02): HTML is big on silent error recovery
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (05:03): yes, I think I heard someone mention that in passing
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (05:03): but I didn't take them seriously
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (05:05): I don't mind silent error recovery when I'm browsing
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (05:05): but I want to be able to serve the best possible content for my readers/users

952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (05:06): I think there's a strong case to keep the differences between html and xhtml to a minimum. Which means that I think SVG and MathML markup should be the same in html5 and xhtml5
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (05:07): They could be the same right?
227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6 (05:07): well, obviously you'll get no argument from me there, but I wasn't talking about SVG (for once)

952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (05:08): But it's not me that I'm worried about
952fcd570c09b3137446717c00bcbdd6 (05:08): other authors will be confused between two syntaxes
